data.title: Where in Western Europe you wouldn't want to live? (developed, conditions, facts)
meta_keywords: Where in Western Europe you wouldn't want to live?
data.meta_description: Originally Posted by Mulhall It also has nothing to do with the British health service but you seem obliged to criticise our health service, so don'
data.text:
Quote:

Originally Posted by patrix542

"northern France" thats it, the rest of France is much warmer and sunnier.

That's what I said

Quote:

Originally Posted by ptrix542

UK weather is worse than Sweden or Denmark, Sweden is sunnier and drier, they also have warmer summers and nice snowy winters.

Germany, Austria and Switzerland often get really hot in the summer with temps well over 30C which is very rare in UK, and its also much drier.

The weather in the UK is not worse than Sweden and Denmark, they might get okay summers at the bottom of Sweden and part of Denmark but they also get very cold winters, far colder than the UK. The average tempreture in Germany is 22C in July, not that great and not much better than the UK. Tempretures in the UK can also exceed 30C in Summer. Austria and Switzerland have massive mountain ranges as well which effects tempretures.

Do you think we in Britain head for the barmy tempretures of Germany, Scandanavia and Switzerland, no we don't., we head to the south and mediterranean or even beyond. You don't hear people saying I tell you what instead of going to the mediterranean lets head for those great Swedish and German beaches.

Mazarron Camposol Weather - Klimaat - Klima - Tiempo - Meteo

Last edited by Mulhall; 05-06-2012 at 05:08 PM..

Quote:

Originally Posted by Mulhall

That's what I said

The weather in the UK is not worse than Sweden and Denmark, they might get okay summers at the bottom of Sweden and part of Denmark but they also get very cold winters, far colder than the UK. The average tempreture in Germany is 22C in July, not that great and not much better than the UK. Tempretures in the UK can also exceed 30C in Summer. Austria and Switzerland have massive mountain ranges as well which effects tempretures.

Do you think we in Britain head for the barmy tempretures of Germany, Scandanavia and Switzerland, no we don't., we head to the south and mediterranean or even beyond. You don't hear people saying I tell you what instead of going to the mediterranean lets head for those great Swedish and German beaches.

Mazarron Camposol Weather - Klimaat - Klima - Tiempo - Meteo

nice maps you found but i lived in poland and germany and now i live in UK and German summers are MUCH armer no matter what is says on the map, 30C in uk is extremely rare while in Germany its usual and it gets over 35C every year too.

as for colder winters... to most of people its a good thing because guess what- winters are supposed to be cold and snowy. UK winters are rainy and depressing and summers very dissapointing.

Many german cities have average july temps over 25C, you will not see that in any British city.. but as i said before these are averages which also include night temperatures which means that daily highs frequently hit 30C while in winter it frequently gets below 0 and snows... but if you think English climate of 5-10C in winter and 18-22C during summer is better then good for you!

Quote:

Originally Posted by patrix542

18-22C during summer

This is pretty much what San Francisco is like in June and July. Its not raining - just a marine overcast/fog, but its quite cool none the less. You do get acclimated to any climate and when you have to go somewhere hot you really feel it. I prefer the "natural air-conditioning" myself. A lot of people do miss the warm summer weather when they first move here though.

Quote:

Originally Posted by Rozenn

I agree with you on the British/German climate thing but gotta say that NO German city averages over 25°C, and by far.

The Rhine valley cities (Mannheim, Karlsruhe, Freiburg...) barely reach 20°C in July/August.

I think what he meant was the average daytime high, which is above 25°C in all of those three cities, and comes close to this value in the entire Rhine valley from the Dutch border (Nijmegen, 24°C) right down to Darmstadt, where it surpasses this mark.

Of course, when one counts the month average, it ranges from slightly over 18°C in Nijmegen to almost 21°C in Freiburg, but this also includes the overnight lows. Averages along the Rhine would be 13/24 in Nijmegen, 14/25 in Cologne, 14/26 in Mannheim and 15/27 in Freiburg.

Except for the home counties, no place in Britain gets anywhere near these values, but to exceed averages of 25°C, one needs to go as far south as around 40 degrees latitude... Averages highs of 25°C can be found as far north as the middle-Rhine though...

Quote:

Originally Posted by patrix542

nice maps you found but i lived in poland and germany and now i live in UK and German summers are MUCH armer no matter what is says on the map, 30C in uk is extremely rare while in Germany its usual and it gets over 35C every year too.

as for colder winters... to most of people its a good thing because guess what- winters are supposed to be cold and snowy. UK winters are rainy and depressing and summers very dissapointing.

Many german cities have average july temps over 25C, you will not see that in any British city.. but as i said before these are averages which also include night temperatures which means that daily highs frequently hit 30C while in winter it frequently gets below 0 and snows... but if you think English climate of 5-10C in winter and 18-22C during summer is better then good for you!

I am British and I have been to Germany. Germany's weather is hardly the mediterranean climate you make it out to be.

Germany weather, climate and geography

Germany Climate Information - ClimateTemp.info, Making Sense of Average Monthly Temperature & Weather Data with Detailed Climate Graphs That Portray Average Rainfall & Sunshine Hours

UK Climate Information - ClimateTemp.info, Making Sense of Average Monthly Temperature & Weather Data with Detailed Climate Graphs That Portray Average Rainfall & Sunshine Hours

British winters are mild be comparison to most countries, we occasionaly get snow, but tempretures rarely plummet to levels associared with Scandanavia.

Given your previous posts regarding the UK, perhaps you should move as you clearly don't like Britain.

Quote:

Originally Posted by patrix542

Why are you surprised that so many people dont wanna live in UK?

UK has one of the worst qualiy of life in western Europe, bad health care, bad weather, very small and expensive houses...

Of course there are good things about UK like in every country, but lets face the reality.

And you also seem to be under the impression that much of Northern Europe has much better weather than us. I suggest you sped sometime in Norway, Sweden and Denmark, whilst even Germany, Belgium and Austria are hardly tropical.

Quote:

Originally Posted by patrix542

well i do consider it bad.

Why did you post some BBC health comparison to USA? this thread has nothing to do with America, its about Europe.

The only country that has worse weather than UK is probably Ireland and maybe Norway, the rest have much better climate.

In every country house sizes vary but on average British houses are tiny

Oh and Patric there are plenty of people with very big houses in the UK, jusy look around the Home Counties, Cheshire and numerous other locations.

Any way Patric, I hope your visit here isn't too miserable and that you don't fall ill, as I wouldn't want our terrible health service having to look after you.

In the meantime I raise a glass of British Sparkling Wine too you.

Champagne giants eye up England as sparkling wines win praise worldwide | Life and style | The Observer

English sparkling wine comes of age with French boost | Life and style | The Guardian

Last edited by Mulhall; 05-07-2012 at 03:55 AM..

Where did i say that Germany is like mediterranean? All i said that german summers are much hotter than UK with averages often higher than 25C and you will never find a city with average tempts like that.

Yes British winters are mild but is it a good thing? i dont think so, maybe for some people but id rather have nice white snow outside with -5C rather than +5 with wind rain and sleet.

Trust me i wouldnt want that service to look after me either... I would probably only get paracetamol anyway
